import sys
import math

# Auto-generated code below aims at helping you parse

secretmessage = input()

# Write an answer using print
# To debug: print("Debug messages...", file=sys.stderr, flush=True)

alphabet = "abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz0123456789 ,.-:ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ"
def decypherit(msg: str)->str:
    ccp=msg[0]
    res = ccp
    for ccm in msg[1:]:
        ccp = res[-1]
        ccp_i = alphabet.find(ccp)+1
        ccm_i = alphabet.find(ccm)+1
        ccr_i = (ccm_i-ccp_i)%len(alphabet)
        res = res+alphabet[ccr_i-1]
    return (res)

print(decypherit(secretmessage))
data.statement:
Anastasia loves sending secret messages to Barnabe. They have their own code.

The messages are written using the following alphabet: {{abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz0123456789 ,.-:ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ}}.
In this alphabet, {{a}} is in the 1st position, {{b}} in the 2nd position, ... {{n}} in the 14th, ... {{A}} in the 42nd, ... {{O}} in the 56th, ... and {{Z}} in the 67th position.

To encrypt a message, here's the method they use, for example, to encrypt {{Anastasia}} into {{AOot.ut1j}}:
1) The first letter remains unchanged: {{A}}.
2) Each subsequent letter is encrypted by shifting it to the right by the position value of the preceding letter.
For instance:
The letter {{n}} is shifted by 42 positions and is transformed in {{O}} ({{n}} - positition 14 - is preceded by {{A}}, which is in the 42th position): 14 + 42 = 56 (O)
The letter {{a}} is shifted by 14 positions and is transformed in {{o}} ({{a}} - position 1 - is preceded by {{n}}, which is in the 14th position): 1 + 14 = 15 (o)
And so on...

If the shift goes beyond the alphabet (67 characters), it wraps around to the beginning of the alphabet (after {{...XYZ}} come {{abcd...}} so {{aZ}} is cyphered in  {{aa}}).

Your goal? Decypher their messages, of course!
